results.title: Silences of the palace = Les Silences du palais
results.creator_credit: Moufida Tlatli, Cinetelfilms, Magfilm and Mat Films
results.brief_description: This atmospheric first feature film from Tunisian director Mufida Tlatli is the story of Alia, the daughter of a beautiful servant in the palace of the last kings of Tunisia. Memories of her childhood, some pleasant, some painful, are brought to the surface when she returns to the crumbling palace that was both her home and her prison after the death of its patriarch - Sid’Ali. A sensitive, lucid portrayal of growing up in a world where women were not only in the palace to serve but were also to submit to the prince’s “rights of the bedchamber”, with luminous performances from Hend Sabri, as the young Alia, and Amel Hedhili as her overly vigilant mother, Khedija. In Arabic with English subtitles.

results.title: Silas Marner
results.creator_credit: Giles Foster, Louis Marks and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Unjustly accused of theft and cast out from a small 19th century religious community in the Midlands, the young Silas Marner seeks solace and solitude in hard work and a new environment. But when he is robbed of his entire savings by the wayward son of the local squire, it seems he has lost everything for a second time, until a young child mysteriously finds her way into his cottage one winter’s night, and Silas Marner’s life is changed forever. A dramatic adaptation of George Eliot’s novel which stars Ben Kingsley and Jenny Agutter.

results.title: Simon
results.creator_credit: Anne Balfour Fraser, Hans Casparius and Independent Cine Art
results.brief_description: Simon, a clumsy and slightly backward boy, joins his young playmates in their games in the woods, but is tormented and finally abandoned by them. In this experimental film, the children were given only a rough outline of each scene and themselves improvised the details. The central theme of bullying and group cruelty pinpoints a private purgatory familiar to every child. The beauty of the woodlands where the action takes place symbolises the supposedly innocent natures of children, stressing the disillusioning contrast with their behaviour.

results.title: Sigmund Freud's Dora (E)
results.creator_credit: Andrew Tyndall, Anthony McCall, Claire Pajaczkowska and Jane Weinstock
results.brief_description: A critique of the representation of women in psychoanalytic discourse is linked, in the form of an ‘essay’, with modes of representation of women’s sexuality in the visual media. Sigmund Freud’s case history of Dora (‘Fragments of an Analysis of a Case of Hysteria’ published in 1905) is ‘re-read’ in three sections: an argument over the politics of psychoanalysis; a thematic linking of psychoanalytic discourse/pornographic film/advertising; and questions, in the form of post cards from Dora, posed about the way women look at themselves. Warning: sexually explicit.

results.title: Sight and sound
results.creator_credit: Gudrun Parker, Nathan Clavier, Don Mulholland and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Lessons take on new life and meaning for children through the magic of films, filmstrips and radio. Everybody goes to the movies, and directly or indirectly learns much of the world. If ordinary movies illumine minds, how much more can be done with specially designed films in schools. We see, for example, how through a film, a class of children “jumps a continent” to visit Mexico, how a filmstrip on cutouts stimulates creative activity; how a radio broadcast can make what might have been a drab history period spring into new, imaginative life. Thanks to “sight and sound,” learning becomes an adventure.

results.title: Silver City
results.brief_description: While travelling by train to Sydney, Nina, a teacher of Polish extraction meets a fellow Pole, Julian, whom she has not seen for many years. They recall their time at “Silver City” the camp for new Australians where they met in 1949. She was drawn to Julian from the start, it did not matter to her that he was married with a child, and they began an affair. Unable to become a teacher at this time due to her lack of qualifications, Nina takes on a job as a domestic in a country hospital. She is then transferred to a camp near Sydney where she again meets up with Julian. Together they are befriended by two Australians and begin to experience the positive side of their new lives in Australia. But when Julian returns to his wife, Nina is devastated. By 1962 she has fulfilled her desire to become a teacher, yet she remains alone.

results.title: Siegfried
results.creator_credit: Brian Large, Otto Schenk and Metropolitan Opera
results.brief_description: Siefried is the third part of Richard Wagner’s cycle of four operas known as “The Ring of the Nibelung”. This opera follows the adventures of Siefried (Siegfried Jerusalem) as he slays the dragon Fafner to gain possession of the ring which gives mastery of the world. He also rescues Brunhilde (Hildegard Behrens) from the ring of fire where she was imprisoned in “Die Walkure”, the second opera from the cycle. This Metropolitan Opera production of “Siegfried” is entertaining, with great sets and strong performances from the entire cast. The Metropolitan Opera Orchestra is conducted by James Levine. There is no subtitling, enabling the viewer to concentrate on the music and performances. Includes guide in English, Italian and German.

results.title: Sick: the life and death of Bob Flanagan, supermasochist (D)
results.brief_description: The title of this powerful documentary about performance artist and cystic fibrosis sufferer Bob Flanagan hits the mark on two levels. In one sense, it describes his physical condition; Flanagan suffered from the disease all his life and died from it at 43. The second, more evocative reference is to the shockingly direct sadomasochism of the artist’s performances. This is not a film for the squeamish, the prudish, or the faint-hearted. Even hardened viewers may feel disconcerted by Flanagan’s performances, which include piercing and penetrating of almost every body part by practically any sharp object. No other artist in history has examined so literally the experience of pain and the associated pleasures of sadomasochism and domination. Dick was also able to record a great deal of the last two years of Flanagan’s life, including his death, creating as comprehensive a portrait of an artist and his work as possible. (Awards: Winner of the Special Artistic Merit Award, Sundance, 1997).

results.title: Showbiz goes to war
results.creator_credit: Gail Gibson Sedawie, Norman Sedawie, Glen-Warren Productions and T A D Productions
results.brief_description: Hosted by David Steinberg, this documentary about Hollywood stars, World War II and the Hollywood film industry, focuses on the three “P’s” - Patriotism, Propaganda, Pin-ups. Films have always proven to be the great escape during times of hardship, and no more so than during World War II. Hollywood and its stars were the number one morale builder for both the troops and the civilians. Nationalism and patriotism were spawned by the image of the all-American war hero on the big screen prepared to die for his country, a symbol of self-sacrifice whilst at the same time portraying the enemy as a cruel and heartless villain to be destroyed no matter the cost. For the troops it was the entertainment provided by the Hollywood stars that kept them going, in particular, the pin-up girls such as Betty Grable, Rita Hayworth, Jane Russell. And of course there was nothing better than a bit of comedy to lighten up their lives through such stars as Bob Hope and Abbott and Costello. “Showbiz goes to war” is a wonderful documentary put together with many classical film excerpts, trailers, archival newsreel footage of World War II, and includes such Hollywood stars as Fred Astaire, Lucille Ball, Humphrey Bogart, Marlene Dietrich, Clark Gable, James Cagney, Judy Garland, Frank Sinatra, Bing Crosby, John Wayne and a cast of thousands. Watch out for that gem of a comedy sketch by Abbott and Costello “Who’s on first?” - it’s a classic.
